questions.text: A 60 years old male patient was undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy. During the surgery, it was observed that there was a sudden decrease in etCO2  to 8 mm Hg, SpO2 was 90%, BP dropped to 80/50 mm Hg and peak airway pressure was observed to be 18 mm Hg. Which of the most probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. CO2 embolism

 

Explanation:

 

In the scenario described, a sudden decrease in end-tidal CO2 (etCO2) to 8 mm Hg, along with a drop in blood pressure (BP) to 80/50 mm Hg and oxygen saturation (SpO2) to 90%, but with normal peak airway pressure (18 mm Hg), strongly suggests a CO2 embolism. During laparoscopic procedures, CO2 is used for insufflation to create a pneumoperitoneum, which can occasionally enter a blood vessel and cause a CO2 embolism. This event leads to a rapid decrease in etCO2 due to reduced return of CO2 to the lungs, hypoxemia, and cardiovascular collapse. The normal peak airway pressures help differentiate it from other causes of acute respiratory distress.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax: A pneumothorax, or collapsed lung, could occur due to barotrauma from mechanical ventilation or surgical complications. However, it typically causes an increase in peak airway pressures due to increased resistance to ventilation. The absence of increased peak airway pressures makes pneumothorax less likely in this case.

 

Option C. Endobronchial Intubation: Endobronchial intubation occurs when the endotracheal tube is inserted too far and intubates one of the main bronchi, typically the right main bronchus. This can lead to hypoventilation of one lung, causing a decrease in etCO2 and SpO2. However, peak airway pressures might be higher due to one-lung ventilation, which was not observed here.

 

Option D. Bronchospasm: Bronchospasm involves the constriction of the muscles in the walls of the bronchioles, leading to narrowed airways. This would usually present with an increase in peak airway pressures due to the narrowed airways, which is not consistent with the normal peak airway pressures reported in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During laparoscopic surgery, the sudden onset of hypotension, hypoxemia, and a significant decrease in etCO2 with normal peak airway pressures suggests a CO2 embolism, a rare but potentially life-threatening complication.

questions.text: Hypokalemia is seen in all of the following conditions, except? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Renal tubular acidosis 4

 

Renal tubular acidosis type 4 (hyperkalemic RTA) is distinct from the other types as it is characterized by hyperkalemia (high potassium levels). It is typically caused by aldosterone deficiency or resistance, leading to impaired potassium secretion. This condition is often associated with Addison's disease, or can be induced by medications such as ACE inhibitors, ARBs, calcineurin inhibitors, heparin, NSAIDs, and potassium-sparing diuretics.

 

Other Options:

 

Hypokalemia, or low potassium levels, is commonly seen in several conditions that lead to normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA). These include:

 

Option A. Renal tubular acidosis (RTA) type 1 (Distal RTA): This condition is characterized by a defect in hydrogen ion secretion in the distal nephron, leading to hypokalemia, hypercalciuria, nephrocalcinosis, and recurrent kidney stones.

 

Option B. Renal tubular acidosis type 2 (Proximal RTA): This condition involves a defect in bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubule, leading to hypokalemia, bicarbonate wasting, and associated Fanconi syndrome (a combination of aminoaciduria, glycosuria, phosphaturia, and bone disorders such as rickets and osteomalacia).

 

Option D. Ureterosigmoidostomy: This surgical procedure can lead to hypokalemia due to the reabsorption of urinary ammonium and chloride, resulting in a metabolic acidosis with hypokalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Renal tubular acidosis type 4 is the exception among conditions causing hypokalemia, as it leads to hyperkalemia due to aldosterone deficiency or resistance.

questions.text: A 32-year-old farmer was brought to the emergency after he suddenly became unconscious while working in the field. On examination, his temperature was 105 degrees Fahrenheit and his skin turgor was decreased. Which of the following would not be seen in the patient?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sweating

 

Explanation

 

In the scenario described, the patient likely suffers from heatstroke, characterized by a high body temperature (105°F), altered consciousness, and dehydration (indicated by decreased skin turgor).

 

Heatstroke is a severe form of heat illness that occurs when the body's heat-dissipating mechanisms fail. One of the classic signs, especially in exertional heatstroke, is the cessation of sweating, despite the elevated body temperature. This lack of sweating is due to dehydration and the body's inability to maintain adequate heat loss through evaporation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Tachypnea - Rapid, deep breathing (Kussmaul breathing) can be seen in heatstroke

 

Option B: Hypotension - Dehydration and vasodilation in an attempt to dissipate heat can result in hypotension in heatstroke.

 

Option D: Red hot skin - Heatstroke patients can present with hot, flushed skin due to increased blood flow to the skin surface and the body's inability to dissipate heat effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Difference between Fever and Heatstroke is as follows:

choices.text: Chronic respiratory acidosis, acute metabolic alkalosis
Acute respiratory acidosis, acute respiratory alkalosis
Acute Metabolic alkalosis, acute respiratory acidosis
Acute respiratory acidosis, acute metabolic alkalosis

questions.text: Identify the areas marked F, C in the following diagram: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute respiratory acidosis, acute respiratory alkalosis

 

  • Area F: Positioned in the lower left part of the diagram, which corresponds to higher PCO2 and a pH less than 7.35. This area represents Acute Respiratory Acidosis due to an increase in CO2, causing a drop in blood pH.
  • Area C: Positioned in the upper right part of the diagram, which corresponds to lower PCO2 and a pH greater than 7.45. This area represents Acute Respiratory Alkalosis caused by a decrease in CO2, increasing blood pH.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the relationship between pH, bicarbonate (HCO3-), and CO2 is crucial for interpreting arterial blood gases. Area F indicates acute respiratory acidosis due to increased CO2, and area C indicates acute respiratory alkalosis due to decreased CO2.

choices.text: Collagen is a type of fibrous protein, which is most abundant of all human proteins
Post translational hydroxylation of proline & lysine
Triple helix is required for its function

questions.text: Which of the following is false about collagen: (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Most abundant AA is Phenyl-alanine

 

Collagen is a fibrous protein that is indeed the most abundant protein in the human body. It provides structural support to various tissues, including skin, bones, tendons, and blood vessels. However, the most abundant amino acid in collagen is actually glycine, not phenylalanine. Glycine makes up approximately one-third of the amino acids in the collagen protein chain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Collagen is a type of fibrous protein that is the most abundant protein in the human body. It forms a strong and flexible structure in various tissues.

 

Option C. Post-translational hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues is an essential process in collagen synthesis. This hydroxylation is necessary for the proper formation and stability of collagen's triple helix structure.

 

Option D. The triple helix structure is a characteristic feature of collagen and is crucial for its function. Collagen molecules are composed of three polypeptide chains, coiled around each other in a triple helical arrangement. This structure provides collagen with its strength and stability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the correct composition of collagen is essential to understand its structural role in the human body.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with post-transcriptional modification? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glycosylation

 

The correct answer is Glycosylation. Glycosylation is a process where sugars are added to proteins or lipids, but it occurs in the endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi apparatus, primarily during and after translation, not during post-transcriptional modifications. Post-transcriptional modifications occur to RNA molecules after they have been transcribed from DNA but before they are translated into proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methylation: Methylation in the context of RNA processing involves the addition of a methyl group, often to the 5' end of the RNA as part of the capping process. For example, a 7-methylguanosine cap is added to the 5' end of the RNA to protect it from degradation and assist in ribosome binding during translation.

 

Option B. Endonuclease cleavage: This is part of the splicing process where introns are removed from the pre-mRNA. Endonucleases cut within the nucleotide sequence, helping to remove non-coding sequences (introns) from the RNA transcript.

 

Option C. Capping: This process involves adding a modified guanine nucleotide (7-methylguanosine) to the 5' end of the RNA. This cap protects the RNA from degradation and is essential for the initiation of translation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycosylation is not a post-transcriptional modification. Post-transcriptional modifications include processes like capping, methylation, and splicing, which are critical for the maturation of mRNA before it is translated into protein.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male was on metronidazole therapy for a bacterial infection. He attended a party and consumed alcohol. Shortly after, he developed symptoms including intense facial flushing, severe nausea, vomiting, headache, dizziness, palpitations, and hypotension. What is the likely cause? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Drug interaction

 

The patient’s symptoms are indicative of a disulfiram-like reaction, which occurs when alcohol is consumed while taking certain medications, including metronidazole. Metronidazole inhibits the enzyme acetaldehyde dehydrogenase, leading to the accumulation of acetaldehyde when alcohol is consumed. This results in symptoms such as facial flushing, nausea, vomiting, headache, dizziness, palpitations, and hypotension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metronidazole overdose: Metronidazole overdose would typically present with neurological symptoms such as seizures, neuropathy, and encephalopathy, rather than the acute symptoms seen here, which are triggered by alcohol consumption.

 

Option B. Methanol poisoning: Methanol poisoning presents with symptoms such as headache, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, visual disturbances, and in severe cases, metabolic acidosis. The context of alcohol consumption and the specific symptoms make methanol poisoning unlikely in this scenario.

 

Option D. Alcohol withdrawal: Alcohol withdrawal typically presents with symptoms such as tremors, agitation, anxiety, hallucinations, and seizures. It does not present with the acute flushing and gastrointestinal symptoms seen in this case, which are more consistent with a disulfiram-like reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Disulfiram-like reaction by "CGMP" (mnemonic)

 

C – Cefoperazone

 

G – Griseofulvin

 

M – Metronidazole

 

P – Procarbazine

 

Additionally, sometimes can be caused by Isoniazid and chlorpropamide.

 

This reaction typically includes symptoms such as flushing, headache, nausea, vomiting, and palpitations when alcohol is consumed.

questions.text: Which muscle is inserted on the lesser trochanter of the femur? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Psoas major

 

  • Psoas major muscle is a paraspinal muscle located deep in the body.
  • It lays close to the spine on either side and extends distally to the brim of the lesser pelvis.
  • It acts to laterally flex the lumbar spine and assists with flexion and external rotation of the hip.
  • It is essential for correct standing or sitting lumbar posture, stability of the hip joint, and during walking and running.
  • The psoas muscle is one of the core muscles.
  • The psoas muscle contains superficial and deep parts.
  • Superficially, it originates along the lateral surface of the distal thoracic vertebrae and adjacent intervertebral discs.
  • The deeper portion originates at the first 4 lumbar vertebrae.
  • The fibres of the muscle converge from its wide origin as they descend on the posterior abdominal wall.
  • They cross the pelvic inlet to form a long tendon, which is joined within the pelvic region by fibres from the iliacus muscle, finally inserting into the lesser trochanter of the femur. 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Psoas minor: The psoas minor muscle originates along the lateral aspect of the vertebral body of the 12th thoracic vertebrae and the 1st lumbar vertebrae, and the intervertebral disc between those two vertebrae. There are two psoas minors, one on each side of the spine. Distally, it blends with the iliopsoas fascia. It inserts into the pectineal line of the pubis (not always present).

 

 

Option C. Obturator internus: The obturator internus muscle originates from the inferior margin of the superior pubic ramus and from the pelvic surface of the obturator membrane. Its tendon exits the pelvis through the lesser sciatic foramen to insert onto the greater trochanter of the femur.

 

 

Option D. Piriformis: It originates from the anterior aspect of the sacrum at the level of S2-S4, sacrotuberous ligament, and periphery of the greater sciatic notch. It inserts on the superior and medial aspects of the greater trochanter.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Psoas Major muscle inserts at the lesser trochanter of the femur and is involved in flexing the hip joint.

questions.text: A patient with O negative and husband B positive delivered a baby. Has received anti-D prophylaxis at 28 weeks. In which of the following conditions will you give anti-D post-delivery? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Baby +ve, DCT -ve

 

In cases where an Rh-negative mother has delivered a baby, the administration of anti-D immunoglobulin post-delivery is crucial if the baby is Rh-positive and the Direct Coombs Test (DCT) is negative.

 

  • Rh incompatibility: The Rh-negative mother may develop antibodies against Rh-positive fetal red blood cells if fetal-maternal hemorrhage occurs. To prevent this alloimmunization and protect future pregnancies, anti-D immunoglobulin is given to neutralize any fetal Rh-positive red blood cells that might have entered the maternal circulation during delivery.
  • Direct Coombs Test (DCT): This test checks whether antibodies are already attached to the baby's red blood cells. A negative DCT indicates that the fetal RBCs are free of maternal antibodies. If the DCT is negative and the baby is Rh-positive, anti-D is administered to the mother to prevent the formation of antibodies in her system.

 

The administration of anti-D within 72 hours of delivery is standard practice to ensure that any fetal red blood cells in the mother’s circulation are neutralized, thereby preventing Rh sensitization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Baby O negative, DCT negative: In this, anti D is not required as the baby's blood group is Rh negative so there is NO risk of isoimmunization

 

Option B. Baby O negative, DCT positive: In this, anti D is not required as the baby's blood group is Rh negative so there is NO risk of iso immunization

 

Option C. Baby Positive, DCT positive: In this patient although the Baby is Rh positive , but DCT is positive which means Abs have already formed in the mother and hence there is no use of giving her Anti D

 

Educational Objective:

 

Administer anti-D immunoglobulin to an Rh-negative mother after delivery if the baby is Rh-positive and the Direct Coombs Test (DCT) is negative to prevent Rh sensitization and protect future pregnancies.

questions.text: A patient presented with Ventricular Tachycardia. What is the best drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amiodarone

 

Explanation

 

For treating ventricular tachycardia (VT), the drug of choice in acute situations according to Advanced Life Support (ALS) protocols is Amiodarone. It is a class III antiarrhythmic medication that works by prolonging the action potential duration and refractory period in the myocardial cells, thus stabilizing the cardiac rhythm.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Adenosine: Ineffective for ventricular tachycardia as it is primarily used for supraventricular tachycardia.

 

Option C. Propranolol: A beta-blocker used for various cardiac conditions, but not typically effective for acute VT.

 

Option D. Ivabradine: Used to reduce heart rate in chronic heart failure and stable angina, not suitable for VT management

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Amiodarone is the best drug for the acute management of ventricular tachycardia due to its efficacy in stabilizing cardiac rhythm by prolonging the action potential and refractory period in myocardial cells.

questions.text: La belle indifference is seen in which of the following conditions? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Conversion disorder

 

La Belle indifference can be seen in Conversion disorder.

 

CONVERSION DISORDER

 

ICD-11 uses the term ‘dissociative neurological symptom disorder’

 

  • Patients present with symptoms suggestive of motor, sensory or cognitive deficits; however, no neurological cause can be found.
  • Also, the symptoms do not conform to the anatomical and physiological principles

 

Patients may have ‘la belle indifference’, which is a lack of concern for the symptoms. E.g., A patient with sudden onset loss of vision in an eye may appear unconcerned with her symptom.

questions.text: Sterilization technique for the tip of disposable glass pipette is: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Autoclaving and 70% ethanol

 

The most effective sterilization technique for the tip of disposable glass pipettes, as indicated by the available methods, is autoclaving in combination with 70% ethanol.

 

Autoclaving is a reliable method of sterilization that involves exposing the material to high temperature and pressure (121°C at 15 psi) for a specific period, typically 20 minutes. This method effectively kills bacteria, viruses, and spores.

 

Chemical disinfectants

 

 

So, 70% ethanol is widely used as a disinfectant due to its ability to denature proteins and dissolve lipids, making it highly effective at eliminating microbial contamination on glass surfaces.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Microwaving and 95% ethanol: Microwaving is not a standard sterilization method for glass pipettes. Although 95% ethanol can be used for disinfection, it is less effective than 70% ethanol because it evaporates too quickly to kill all microbes thoroughly.

 

Option B. Autoclaving: While autoclaving alone is an effective sterilization method, the question specifies the tip of disposable glass pipettes, where combining it with 70% ethanol enhances the sterilization process.

 

Option D. Hot air oven: A hot air oven can be used for sterilization, but it requires longer exposure times at higher temperatures. This method is less efficient compared to autoclaving combined with ethanol, especially for small, delicate items like pipette tips.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most effective sterilization technique for the tip of disposable glass pipettes is autoclaving combined with 70% ethanol. Autoclaving provides high heat and pressure to eliminate microorganisms, while 70% ethanol ensures thorough disinfection.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman complains of fatigue, weight gain, and increased sensitivity to cold. On physical examination, she has noticeable swelling in her neck the histological image is shown below. Additionally, an ultrasound examination shows that her thyroid gland is diffusely enlarged and has an uneven texture. Which of the following conditions is most likely the cause of her symptoms? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hashimoto’s thyroiditis

 

The given findings are suggestive of diffuse goitre with clinical hypothyroidism, suggestive of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis.

 

Hashimoto's thyroiditis, also known as chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis, is an autoimmune disorder that results in the destruction of the thyroid gland. Patients often present with hypothyroidism symptoms, such as fatigue, weight gain, and cold sensitivity. As for the histological findings, Hashimoto's thyroiditis is characterized by:

 

  1. Lymphocytic infiltration with germinal centers.
  2. Follicular cell damage.
  3. Reduced colloid and increased fibrous tissue.
  4. Presence of Hurthle cells (or Askanazy cells) which are oxyphilic cells with a granular cytoplasm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medullary carcinoma: Medullary thyroid carcinoma originates from parafollicular C cells in the thyroid gland. These cells produce calcitonin, and the carcinoma often increases levels of this hormone. The tumor can appear as a firm mass in the neck. Histologically, it contains nests or sheets of cells in an amyloid stroma. It doesn't show the typical lymphocytic infiltration seen in Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Clinical hypothyroidism is not a feature.

 

Option B. Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma: Rarely, the thyroid gland can be affected by primary thyroid lymphoma, which often arises in the setting of Hashimoto's thyroiditis. However, it would be differentiated by its histological appearance, with large numbers of lymphoid cells but lacking the characteristic features of Hashimoto's, such as Hurthle cells. Hypothyroidism is not a feature.

 

Option C. Grave's disease: Grave's disease is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism. It is an autoimmune disorder where antibodies stimulate the thyroid gland, leading to overproduction of thyroid hormones. Symptoms might include weight loss, increased heart rate, tremors, and exophthalmos (bulging eyes). The histology of Grave's disease is characterized by tall, columnar epithelial cells and scalloped colloid, which is different from the described histological findings.

 

Educational Objective:


Hashimoto's thyroiditis is an autoimmune disorder characterized by lymphocytic infiltration of the thyroid gland, leading to hypothyroidism with symptoms such as fatigue, weight gain, and increased sensitivity to cold.

questions.text: Match the following in the Japanese encephalitis virus life cycle? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b

 

The image depicts the life cycle of the Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), which involves various hosts and vectors. Here's the correct matching:

 

  1. Accidental host (Human) - c: Humans are considered accidental hosts for JEV as they do not contribute to the ongoing transmission cycle.
  2. Amplifier (Pigs) - d: Pigs serve as amplifier hosts where the virus replicates to high levels, increasing the likelihood of mosquito transmission.
  3. Reservoir (Ardeid bird) - a: Birds, particularly Ardeid birds (herons and egrets), act as natural reservoirs of JEV.
  4. Vector (Culex) - b: Culex mosquitoes are the primary vectors that transmit JEV from reservoir hosts to amplifier hosts and to accidental hosts.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the Japanese encephalitis virus life cycle:

 

  • Humans are accidental hosts.
  • Pigs are amplifier hosts.
  • Ardeid birds are reservoir hosts.
  • Culex mosquitoes are the vectors responsible for transmission.

questions.text: Which of the following is given as a part of the therapy for a child with severe COVID? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Corticosteroids.

 

In the management of severe COVID-19 in children, corticosteroids are the primary treatment among the given options. Corticosteroids are recommended for children with severe cases, which include conditions like acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), severe pneumonia, septic shock, and multi-organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS).

 

Severe COVID-19 is characterized by symptoms such as SpO2 less than 90% on room air, severe chest retractions, grunting, lethargy, and signs of pneumonia with cyanosis. In these cases, corticosteroids like Dexamethasone or Methylprednisolone are used to reduce inflammation and manage the severe immune response associated with the virus.

 

Guidelines for Steroid Use in Severe COVID-19:

 

  • Indications: Corticosteroids are indicated in rapidly progressive moderate cases and all severe cases. They are generally avoided in the first 3-5 days of illness due to the risk of increased viral shedding during this period.
  • Dosage: Dexamethasone is given at a dose of 0.15 mg/kg with a maximum dose of 6 mg once a day, or Methylprednisolone at 0.75 mg/kg with a maximum dose of 30 mg once a day.
  • Duration: The treatment typically continues for 5-6 days and then is tapered off.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ivermectin: Ivermectin is not recommended for the treatment of severe COVID-19 in children. Ivermectin has been used for deworming, not for treating COVID-19.

 

Option C. Remdesivir: Remdesivir is an antiviral medication used in some hospitalized patients with mild to moderate COVID-19 but is not the primary treatment for severe cases in children. It inhibits viral replication by terminating RNA transcription prematurely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corticosteroids are recommended for the treatment of severe COVID-19 in children to manage inflammation and the severe immune response associated with the virus.

choices.text: Surgical management is required in most children

questions.text: Which of the following is true about laryngomalacia? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Most common in newborn

 

Laryngomalacia is indeed most common in newborns and is often noticed shortly after birth. It is the most common cause of stridor in infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laryngomalacia typically presents with inspiratory stridor, not expiratory. This stridor is due to the collapse of supraglottic structures during inhalation.

 

Option B. The stridor of laryngomalacia typically worsens in the supine position. This is because the supraglottic structures are more likely to collapse into the airway when a child is lying on their back.

 

Option D. Most children with laryngomalacia do not require surgical management. The condition is often self-limiting and tends to improve as the child grows and the laryngeal structures become more rigid, usually by 18 to 24 months of age. Surgery is reserved for severe cases where there are feeding difficulties, failure to thrive, severe stridor, or apnea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngomalacia is characterized by inspiratory stridor that typically worsens in the supine position and is most commonly diagnosed in newborns. The condition generally resolves on its own without the need for surgical intervention in most cases.

questions.text:
Substances and the type of transport across a membrane are given below, choose the correct combination: (INICET Nov 2022)

 

  1. Oxygen: Simple diffusion
  2. Glucose: Facilitated diffusion
  3. Sodium: Voltage-gated channel
  4. Sodium: Secondary active transport
  5. Calcium: Active transport
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 are correct

 

All the given combinations are correct for the types of transport across a membrane:

 

1. Oxygen. Simple diffusion: Oxygen is a non-polar molecule and diffuses directly across the lipid bilayer of cell membranes by simple diffusion. This process does not require any membrane proteins or energy input.

 

2. Glucose. Facilitated diffusion: Glucose is transported into cells via facilitated diffusion, which involves specific carrier proteins (such as GLUT transporters). This process allows glucose to move down its concentration gradient without the use of energy.

 

3. Sodium. Voltage-gated channel: Voltage-gated sodium channels are integral membrane proteins that open and close in response to changes in membrane potential. These channels allow the selective passage of sodium ions during the action potentials in neurons and muscle cells.

 

4. Sodium. Secondary active transport: Sodium ions are also involved in secondary active transport, where the movement of sodium down its electrochemical gradient (established by primary active transport) drives the transport of another substance against its gradient. An example is the sodium-glucose cotransporter (SGLT).

 

5. Calcium. Active transport: Calcium ions are actively transported across cell membranes using ATP-driven pumps such as the Ca²⁺-ATPase (also known as the calcium pump). This process maintains low intracellular calcium levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

All of the mentioned substances and their associated transport mechanisms are correct: Oxygen via simple diffusion, glucose via facilitated diffusion, sodium via voltage-gated channels and secondary active transport, and calcium via active transport.

questions.text: A 65-year-old chronic smoker came to the medicine outpatient department with complaints of upper chest discomfort and drooping of an eyelid. He also complained of pain radiating to the upper arm and a tingling sensation in the 4th and 5th digits of his left hand. The chest X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pancoast tumor

 

Pancoast tumors, also known as superior sulcus tumors, are a type of lung cancer located at the apex (top) of the lung. These tumors are particularly associated with several key clinical features and findings, especially in chronic smokers:

 

  1. Upper chest discomfort: This is a common symptom of a Pancoast tumor due to the tumor's location at the apex of the lung.
  2. Drooping of an eyelid (ptosis): This is part of Horner's syndrome, which occurs due to compression of the sympathetic nerves by the tumor. Horner's syndrome typically includes ptosis (drooping eyelid), miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating) on the affected side of the face.
  3. Pain radiating to the upper arm and tingling sensation: These symptoms suggest involvement of the brachial plexus, a network of nerves that supplies the arm and hand. Pancoast tumors often invade or compress these nerves, leading to referred pain and sensory disturbances in the arm and hand.
  4. Chest X-ray findings: The provided chest X-ray shows a mass at the apex of the lung, which is characteristic of a Pancoast tumor.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Upper lobe pneumonia: While upper lobe pneumonia can cause chest discomfort and possibly pain, it is not associated with Horner's syndrome or brachial plexus involvement. The X-ray findings would also typically show consolidation rather than a mass.

 

Option C. Superior vena cava obstruction: This condition can cause swelling and discoloration of the face, neck, and upper extremities due to impaired blood flow. However, it does not explain the specific nerve-related symptoms like Horner's syndrome or tingling in the digits.

 

Option D. Aspergilloma: Aspergillomas are fungal balls that develop in pre-existing lung cavities, usually in patients with a history of tuberculosis or other lung diseases. They do not typically present with the neurological symptoms seen in this case, nor do they commonly cause Horner's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pancoast tumors, or superior sulcus tumors, are associated with upper chest discomfort, Horner's syndrome, and neurological symptoms in the arm due to their apical location and propensity to invade local structures such as the brachial plexus and sympathetic nerves.

choices.text: It uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum
It can be confirmatory test of trisomy 13, 18 and 21
It can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation
It is done after the routine first trimester ultrasound assessment

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about non-invasive prenatal testing? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It can be confirmatory test of trisomy 13, 18 and 21

 

Explanation:

 

Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) is a screening tool, not a diagnostic tool. It uses cell-free fetal DNA circulating in the maternal serum to screen for certain genetic conditions, including trisomies 13, 18, and 21.

 

NIPT is not used for diagnosis but for screening. It has high sensitivity (about 99%) for detecting trisomies 21, 18, and 13, but positive results must be confirmed with diagnostic tests such as chorionic villus sampling (CVS) or amniocentesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum: Correct. NIPT uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum to assess the risk of certain genetic conditions in the fetus.

 

Option C. It can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation: Correct. NIPT can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation, when there is enough fetal DNA in the maternal blood for accurate analysis.

 

Option D. It is done after the routine first trimester ultrasound assessment: Correct. NIPT is often done after the routine first trimester ultrasound assessment, which helps determine gestational age and detect multiple pregnancies or major anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) is a screening test for aneuploidy using cell-free fetal DNA in maternal serum, typically performed after 10 weeks of gestation.

 

Ref: Page 890, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Decreased bearing down efforts by the mother
Cervical Dilatation of 8 cm

questions.text: Ventouse is contra-indicated in? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Preterm

 

Ventouse (vacuum extraction) is contraindicated in preterm deliveries due to the increased risk of neonatal complications. The head of a preterm baby is more vulnerable to injury, and the use of vacuum can lead to severe complications such as neurological damage, cephalohematoma, or skull fractures. This is because the vacuum exerts force on the baby’s head, which is particularly fragile in preterm infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased bearing down efforts by the mother: This is not an absolute contraindication for vacuum delivery. In fact, vacuum extraction is often used when there are decreased maternal efforts during the second stage of labor.

 

Option B. Heart disease: Maternal heart disease is not a contraindication for vacuum extraction. However, it may influence the choice of delivery method to minimize maternal stress.

 

Option D. Cervical Dilatation of 8 cm: While full cervical dilation (10 cm) is ideal for vacuum extraction, it is a relative contraindication rather than an absolute one. In urgent situations where cesarean section is not feasible, vacuum extraction might still be considered even if the cervix is not fully dilated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Absolute Contraindication of Ventouse:

 

  • Preterm
  • Face presentation
  • After coming head of the breech
  • IUD

questions.text: The relaxation of the intestinal segment distal to the segment with the bolus of food during peristalsis is because of? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) VIP

 

The relaxation of the intestinal segment distal to the segment with the bolus of food during peristalsis is due to the release of VIP (Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide) from the enteric nervous system.

 

VIP is a neuropeptide that is released by neurons in the myenteric plexus of the enteric nervous system. It causes relaxation of the smooth muscle in the intestinal wall, including the distal segment, through its action on VIP receptors located on the smooth muscle cells. This relaxation allows the bolus of food to move smoothly along the digestive tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Substance P: Incorrect. Substance P is a neuropeptide involved in the regulation of gastrointestinal motility, primarily stimulating smooth muscle contraction rather than relaxation.

 

Option C. Dopamine from adrenergic fibres: Incorrect. Dopamine from adrenergic fibers is involved in the regulation of gastrointestinal motility, but it is not specifically responsible for the relaxation of the intestinal segment distal to the bolus of food during peristalsis.

 

Option D. Acetylcholine from myenteric fibres: Incorrect. Acetylcholine from myenteric fibers is a neurotransmitter involved in the regulation of gastrointestinal motility, typically promoting contraction rather than relaxation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The relaxation of the intestinal segment distal to the bolus of food during peristalsis is mediated by the release of Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide (VIP) from the enteric nervous system, which causes smooth muscle relaxation and facilitates the smooth movement of the bolus through the digestive tract.

questions.text: Our physiology is designed to detect harmful substances through the perception of bitterness. Which of the substances listed below is accountable for causing this bitter taste?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alkaloids

 

Alkaloids binding to receptor à activation of GPCR à IP3/ DAG à ↑intracellular Ca2+ à  secrete ATP which in turn excites sensory afferent fibers à  bitter taste.

 

TASTE

 

 

 

 

Poison, alkaloids are bitter in taste.



Sweet    Sugars (e.g. glucose, sucrose), alcohols (e.g. ethanol), aspartame, aldehydes (like vanillin, cinnamaldehyde)
Sour    Acids (e.g. citric acid, lactic acid), H⁺ ions
Salty    Sodium ions (Na⁺), other metal salts like K⁺ or Li⁺ salts
Bitter    Alkaloids (e.g. quinine, caffeine), poisons, toxins
Umami    Glutamate (e.g. monosodium glutamate - MSG), some nucleotides (e.g. inosinate, guanylate)
 

 

  • Anterior 2/3rd → Chorda Tympani → 7th Nerve
  • Posterior 1/3rd → 9th Nerve
  • Posterior most (pharynx & palate) → 10th Nerve

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amino acids: Incorrect. Amino acids are not typically responsible for a bitter taste; they are usually associated with the umami taste.

 

Option C. Hydrogen ions: Incorrect. Hydrogen ions are responsible for the sour taste, not bitterness.

 

Option D. Aldehydes: Incorrect. Aldehydes are generally associated with sweet or fruity tastes, not bitterness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alkaloids are the substances responsible for causing a bitter taste, activating G-protein-coupled receptors and the IP3/DAG pathway, leading to an increase in intracellular Ca2+ and the excitation of sensory afferent fibers.

choices.text: Transferrin saturation
RBC protoporphyrin
Total iron binding capacity
Serum transferrin receptors

questions.text: In iron deficiency anemia all of the following is increased except? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transferrin saturation

 

Transferrin Saturation: This is the percentage of transferrin (the protein that transports iron in the blood) that is saturated with iron. In iron deficiency anemia, the transferrin saturation is decreased because there is less iron available to bind to transferrin.

 

It is important to note that in a patient with iron deficiency anemia, there is increased TIBC as well as increased RBC Protoporphyrin levels and the number of serum transferrin receptors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RBC protoporphyrin: This is a precursor in the heme synthesis pathway. In iron deficiency anemia, the lack of iron means that protoporphyrin accumulates, as it cannot be converted into heme. Therefore, RBC protoporphyrin levels are increased.

 

Option C. Total iron binding capacity (TIBC): This is a measure of the total capacity of the blood to bind iron with transferrin. In iron deficiency anemia, TIBC is increased as the body produces more transferrin in an attempt to capture more iron from the diet and the body’s stores.

 

Option D. Serum transferrin receptors: These receptors are present on the surface of cells and are involved in the uptake of transferrin-bound iron. In iron deficiency anemia, the number of these receptors increases as the body tries to increase iron uptake from the blood.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following would be prescribed for simple myopic astigmatism?  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. -1.00 DC X 180 degree

 

  • The correct prescription for simple myopic astigmatism is -1.00 DC × 180 degrees.
  • Simple myopic astigmatism means that one principal meridian of the eye is in focus on the retina, while the other principal meridian is in front of the retina.
  • There are three components to the prescription of glasses for astigmatism: 
    1. The power of the spherical component (convex or concave dioptre sphere),
    2. The power of the cylinder (convex or concave dioptre cylinder),
    3. The axis (orientation) of the cylinder.

 

For example: -1.00 DC × 180 degree

 

This prescription indicates that the individual has simple astigmatism, which means one meridian of the eye is in focus while the other is not. In this case, the unfocused meridian is myopic (nearsighted) and requires correction with a concave cylinder lens. The strength of the cylinder lens is -1.00 diopters (DC). The axis of the cylinder is oriented at 180 degrees, which represents the meridian that is most affected by astigmatism.

 

Types of astigmatism:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. +1.00 DS: This represents a convex spherical lens for hypermetropia (farsightedness) and is not used for astigmatism correction.

 

Option C. -1.00 DS: This represents a concave spherical lens for simple myopia (nearsightedness) but does not correct astigmatism.

 

Option D. -1.00 DS -1.00 DC X 180 degree: This represents a prescription for compound myopic astigmatism, where both meridians are myopic, one corrected by the spherical component and the other by the cylindrical component.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Simple myopic astigmatism requires correction with a cylindrical lens that corrects the myopic meridian, typically specified with the cylinder power and the axis. The correct prescription for simple myopic astigmatism in this case is -1.00 DC X 180 degrees.

questions.text: A child presents with sudden loss of vision in one eye, pain on eye movement and there was RAPD. This is due to the lesion of:(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Optic nerve

 

The symptoms described are indicative of an issue at the level of the optic nerve, such as optic neuritis, which can cause sudden vision loss, pain on movement of the eye, and RAPD.

 

The optic nerve transmits visual information from the eye to the brain. A lesion in the optic nerve can cause sudden vision loss in one eye, pain with eye movement (often associated with optic neuritis), and an RAPD, where the pupil of the affected eye does not respond as well to light as the unaffected eye due to the reduced sensory input from the retina.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Optic Chiasma: The optic chiasma is the part of the brain where the optic nerves partially cross. Lesions at this location typically produce visual field defects in both eyes, such as bitemporal hemianopia, where both outer (temporal) halves of the visual field are lost. It would not typically cause sudden vision loss in one eye, nor would it be associated with pain on eye movement.

 

Option B. Optic Tract: The optic tract carries visual information from the optic chiasma to the lateral geniculate nucleus and other areas. Lesions here can result in homonymous hemianopia, where the same visual field cut is observed in both eyes. Like with optic chiasma lesions, optic tract issues do not typically cause sudden unilateral vision loss or pain on eye movement.

 

Option C. Visual Cortex: The visual cortex is located in the back of the brain and is responsible for processing visual information. Damage to the visual cortex can cause a variety of complex visual disturbances, including homonymous hemianopia or cortical blindness, depending on the extent and location of the damage. However, it would not cause unilateral vision loss, pain on eye movement, nor an RAPD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presentation of sudden vision loss in one eye, pain on eye movement, and RAPD suggests a lesion in the optic nerve.

questions.text: Recommended HPV vaccination schedule for 9- to 14-year-olds according to WHO SAGE guidelines is: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 or 2 doses

 

Recommended Schedule:

 

  • One or Two-Dose Schedule:
    • One dose is considered sufficient for healthy individuals aged 9–14 years.
    • Alternatively, a two-dose schedule may be administered, with the second dose given 6–12 months after the first.

 

Key Considerations:

 

  • Primary Target Group: Girls aged 9–14 years, ideally before the onset of sexual activity.
  • Immunocompromised Individuals: Should receive at least two doses, and where feasible, three doses, regardless of age.
  • Vaccination of Boys: While the primary focus is on girls, vaccinating boys is recommended where feasible and affordable to enhance herd immunity and prevent HPV-related diseases in males. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WHO SAGE guidelines recommend 1 or 2 doses of HPV vaccine for 9- to 14-year-olds.

questions.text:
The correct order of events of lactation in the puerperium are? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)

 

  1. Lactogenesis
  2. Mammogenesis
  3. Galactopoiesis
  4. Galactokinesis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 1, 4, 3

 

Explanation:

 

The process of lactation involves several stages, each with specific physiological changes. Understanding these stages helps in comprehending the sequence of events that occur from the preparation of the breast during pregnancy to the maintenance of milk production.

 

2. Mammogenesis: This is the first stage, involving the development and growth of the mammary glands in preparation for lactation. It occurs during pregnancy when the breast tissue proliferates and differentiates under the influence of hormones such as estrogen and progesterone.

 

1. Lactogenesis: This stage refers to the initiation of milk production, which begins around the time of birth. Lactogenesis is divided into two phases:
 

  • Lactogenesis I: Occurs during pregnancy when the mammary gland is capable of producing some milk.
  • Lactogenesis II: Occurs postpartum when copious milk secretion begins, typically around 2-3 days after delivery, driven by the sudden drop in progesterone and the increase in prolactin.

 

4. Galactokinesis: This stage involves the ejection or movement of milk from the alveoli to the nipple. It is facilitated by the let-down reflex, which is triggered by the hormone oxytocin. Oxytocin causes the myoepithelial cells around the alveoli to contract, expelling the milk into the ducts and out through the nipple.

 

3. Galactopoiesis: This final stage refers to the maintenance of milk production. It is sustained by the regular removal of milk from the breast, either through breastfeeding or pumping, which maintains prolactin levels and keeps the milk supply ongoing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of events in lactation during the puerperium is: Mammogenesis (breast development), Lactogenesis (initiation of milk production), Galactokinesis (milk ejection), and Galactopoiesis (maintenance of milk production).

choices.text: Stop pyrazinamide and continue the rest of the drugs with kidney function test (KFT) monitoring.
Add uric acid-lowering drugs and continue antitubercular therapy (ATT) as such with liver function test (LFT) and KFT monitoring.
Continue all drugs and monitor serum uric acid level as well as LFT and KFT.
Stop all ATT drugs until laboratory values return to normal.

questions.text: A patient undergoing antitubercular therapy reports joint pain 10 days after initiation of treatment. Laboratory tests reveal normal AST and ALT levels, a serum creatinine of 0.9 mg/dL, and an elevated serum uric acid level of 10 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient's treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stop pyrazinamide and continue the rest of the drugs with kidney function test (KFT) monitoring.

 

Pyrazinamide is known to increase uric acid levels as a side effect, and hyperuricemia can lead to joint pain, which is suggestive of gout. If the patient's liver function tests are within normal limits, but they have elevated serum uric acid levels and are experiencing joint pain, the likely culprit is pyrazinamide.

 

Option A is the best next step because:

 

  • Stopping pyrazinamide, which is most likely causing the hyperuricemia, should lead to a decrease in uric acid levels and an improvement in joint pain.
  • The rest of the antitubercular drugs can be continued to ensure the treatment of tuberculosis, with monitoring of kidney function tests to ensure the patient does not develop nephrotoxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Add uric acid-lowering drugs and continue antitubercular therapy (ATT) as such with liver function test (LFT) and KFT monitoring: Adding uric acid-lowering drugs might not be necessary immediately if pyrazinamide is discontinued. The primary goal is to identify and stop the drug causing the hyperuricemia.

 

Option C. Continue all drugs and monitor serum uric acid level as well as LFT and KFT: Continuing all drugs without modification might not address the underlying issue of hyperuricemia caused by pyrazinamide, potentially worsening the patient's symptoms.

 

Option D. Stop all ATT drugs until laboratory values return to normal: Stopping all ATT drugs would not be recommended as it could lead to the development of drug-resistant tuberculosis and could be harmful to the overall treatment of the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyrazinamide can cause hyperuricemia and joint pain; stopping pyrazinamide while continuing other antitubercular drugs with monitoring is the appropriate management strategy.

questions.text: A 22y female is overdue by 2 weeks. She visits the OPD with complaints of vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain on the right side. On Examination, her vitals are stable. Abdomen examination is unremarkable. A bimanual examination reveals a bulky, soft uterus with no tenderness and no adnexal mass. Mild bleeding +. Beta hCG is 1400 IU. An ultrasound reveals a trilaminar endometrium, and both the adnexa are normal. The next best step is?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Repeat serum beta HCG after 48h

 

Explanation:

 

  • Repeat serum beta hCG after 48h:
    • The clinical scenario suggests a pregnancy of unknown location (PUL), which could either be a failing intrauterine pregnancy or an ectopic pregnancy.
    • The best next step is to repeat the serum beta hCG level after 48 hours. A rise in beta hCG by at least 66% would suggest a viable intrauterine pregnancy, while a plateau or drop would indicate a non-viable pregnancy, such as an ectopic pregnancy or a failing intrauterine pregnancy.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Diagnostic laparoscopy: Diagnostic laparoscopy is an invasive procedure and is not the immediate next step in the management of a stable patient with PUL. It is reserved for cases where there is a high suspicion of ectopic pregnancy with unstable vital signs or inconclusive non-invasive tests.

 

Option C. Repeat USG after 3 days: Repeating the ultrasound after 3 days may not provide additional useful information if the initial ultrasound did not show an intrauterine pregnancy. Monitoring beta hCG levels first is more informative and guides the need for further imaging.

 

Option D. Wait and watch: Simply waiting without further evaluation could delay diagnosis and appropriate management, especially in the case of a potential ectopic pregnancy, which can be life-threatening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of pregnancy of unknown location (PUL), the next best step is to repeat the serum beta hCG level after 48 hours to differentiate between a viable intrauterine pregnancy and a non-viable pregnancy, such as an ectopic pregnancy or a failing intrauterine pregnancy.

 

 

Ref: page no 378, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition, https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/ng126

questions.text: A patient with a malignancy is undergoing chemotherapy. The platelet counts were reduced after the previous cycle of chemotherapy. Which of the following drugs can be used in the treatment of this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oprelvekin (IL-11)

 

Oprelvekin (IL-11) is a recombinant form of interleukin-11, which is used to prevent severe thrombocytopenia and reduce the need for platelet transfusions following myelosuppressive chemotherapy in patients with non-myeloid malignancies. Oprelvekin works by stimulating the proliferation and maturation of megakaryocytes, the precursor cells to platelets, thereby increasing platelet counts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Filgrastim: Filgrastim is a granulocyte-colony stimulating factor (G-CSF), used in treatment of neutropenia post-chemotherapy.

 

Option C. Erythropoietin: Erythropoietin like Darbepoetin is indicated in Anemia due to chronic kidney disease and bone marrow suppression.

 

Option D. Amifostine: Amifostine is indicated in cisplatin induced nephrotoxicity

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oprelvekin (IL-11) is the drug of choice for managing chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia by increasing platelet counts, thereby reducing the need for platelet transfusions in patients undergoing myelosuppressive chemotherapy.

questions.text: A person arrived with a lesion on their left buttock. This individual has a past medical record of undergoing a heart transplant 15 years ago. Analysis of the fluid extracted from the lesion reveals the presence of gram-positive filamentous bacteria. What is the probable microbial agent responsible for this condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nocardia

 

The provided clinical situation involving a localized abscess and an aspirate displaying filamentous gram-positive bacteria indicates a likelihood of Nocardia infection.

 

  • Nocardia is a gram-positive branching filamentous bacilli.

 

 

  • Modified acid-fast staining: using 1% sulfuric acid as decolorizer (Kinyoun method): Nocardiae are partially acid-fast and appear as branching and filamentous red colored acid-fast bacilli.

 

 

  • Histopathology (H and E stain) of the granules: Shows multilobulated with sun-ray appearance.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Bacillus anthracis, on culture, are arranged end-to-end in long chains → Bamboo-stick appearance.

 

 

Option C. Mycobacterium leprae is an acid-fast, Gram-positive, rod shaped bacterium and an obligate intracellular parasite.

 

 

Option D. Mycobacterium tuberculosis appear weakly Gram-positive. Acid fast stain is used to identify it.

 

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Nocardia is a gram-positive, branching filamentous bacillus, particularly seen in immunocompromised patients, and can be identified using modified acid-fast staining.

choices.text: Antibiotics are the only effective treatment for a Crohn's mass.
Symptomatic relapse following surgery is not related to the presence of disease during resection.
Crohn's disease most commonly involves the proximal ileum.
Continuous lesions observed during endoscopic examination are diagnostic of Crohn's disease.

questions.text: Which of these is a true statement about Crohn’s disease?( NEET PG 2018 )
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Symptomatic relapse following surgery is not related to the presence of disease during resection

 

Symptomatic relapse following surgery is not related to the presence of disease during resection. The course of the disease after surgery is unpredictable since surgery does not cure Crohn's disease. The recurrence of Crohn's disease after surgery is common, and the likelihood of relapse may depend on the extent of disease involvement, the type of surgery performed, and other individual factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antibiotics are not the only effective treatment for a Crohn's mass. Treatment options for Crohn's disease depend on the severity of the disease and may include anti-inflammatory drugs, immunosuppressants, and biologic agents, in addition to antibiotics.

 

Option C. The distal ileum is a common site of involvement in Crohn's disease, but the disease can affect any part of the digestive tract from the mouth to the anus. In addition to the ileum, other common sites of involvement include the colon, and perianal region.

 

Option D. The characteristic features of Crohn's disease on endoscopy include skip lesions, areas of inflammation, ulcers, and strictures, which may be continuous or segmental in nature.

 

Educational Objective:


Surgical resection in Crohn's disease does not cure the condition, and symptomatic relapse can occur independently of the presence of disease at the resection margins.

questions.text: Which of the following will halter the maturity of collagen?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scurvy

 

Option B. Scurvy:

  • Scurvy is a nutritional deficiency disease caused by a lack of vitamin C (ascorbic acid).
  • Vitamin C is essential for the synthesis of collagen. Without adequate vitamin C, collagen production is impaired, leading to the characteristic symptoms of scurvy, including impaired wound healing and gum bleeding.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Beri-Beri:

  • Beri-Beri is a nutritional deficiency disease caused by a lack of vitamin B1 (thiamine).
  • Thiamine deficiency primarily affects the nervous system and cardiovascular system and does not directly impact collagen maturity.

 

Option C. Night Blindness:

  • Night blindness is often associated with a deficiency in vitamin A (retinol).
  • Vitamin A deficiency primarily affects vision and does not directly impact collagen maturity.

 

Option D. Rickets:

  • Rickets is a nutritional deficiency disease caused by a lack of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate.
  • Vitamin D plays a role in calcium and phosphate homeostasis, which is crucial for bone health but does not directly impact collagen maturity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scurvy is the condition that will halt the maturity of collagen because it is caused by a deficiency in vitamin C, which is essential for collagen synthesis.

 

Ascorbic acid is necessary for the post-translational hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues.

 

 

Hydroxyproline and hydroxylysine are essential for the formation of cross links in the collagen, which gives the tensile strength to the fibers. This process is absolutely necessary for the normal production of supporting tissues such as osteoid, collagen and intercellular cement substance of capillaries.

 

Thus, in ascorbic acid deficiency (Scurvy), collagen is abnormal and the intercellular cement substance is brittle. So, capillaries are fragile, leading to the tendency to bleed even under minor pressure.

choices.text: In children, equally among males and females
In adults, equally among males and females
In adults, occurs more in males than in females
In children, occurs more in females than in males

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presented with sudden-onset blindness for the past 4 hours. However, on history taking, it is noted that she is not concerned about it. However, she is concerned that her mother passed away recently and that she should have spent more time with her. Physical examination findings are normal. Which of the following is true about the condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) In children, occurs more in females than in males

 

The patient is likely experiencing a conversion disorder, also known as functional neurological symptom disorder. It's characterized by neurological symptoms (such as blindness, paralysis, or seizures) that can't be explained by medical evaluation and are presumably linked to psychological factors. The indifference towards the symptom (e.g., not being concerned about sudden blindness) is termed "la belle indifférence," although this feature is not always present.

 

In pediatric populations, females are more commonly affected than males.

 

Other Others:

 

Option A. In children, equally among males and females: Incorrect. In children, the condition is more common in females.

 

Option B. In adults, equally among males and females: Incorrect. In adults, conversion disorder is more common in females than in males.

 

Option C. In adults, occurs more in males than in females: Incorrect. The disorder is more common in females than in males in both adults and children.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Conversion disorder, also known as dissociative neurological symptom disorder, is characterized by neurological symptoms that can't be explained by a medical condition and are believed to arise in response to psychological stressors. The symptoms do not conform with anatomical and physiological principles. The condition is more common in females in both pediatric and adult populations.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 451-467.

choices.text: Bipartite patella; X-ray of other knee

questions.text: Shown below is an X-ray of a patient with history of a chronic knee pain. True statement concerning the X-ray shown would be: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bipartite patella; X-ray other knee

 

BIPARTITE PATELLA

 

  • It is the congenital fragmentation of patella.
  • In this condition, the patella is made up of two separate bones instead of one.
  • It occurs when the patella fails to fuse properly during development, leading to a bipartite appearance.
  • This condition is typically asymptomatic and may go unnoticed for many years.
  • In some cases, it can cause pain, swelling, or discomfort, especially during physical activity.
  • The X-ray of opposite knee must be taken as the condition is bilateral in 50% of cases and this condition is more common in males than females.

 

 

  • Management usually involves conservative measures to alleviate symptoms like rest, ice, and physical therapy to strengthen the Quadriceps muscles, and reduce stress on the patella.
  • In more severe cases, a brace may be recommended to provide additional support and reduce stress on the patella.
  • Pain medications and anti-inflammatory drugs may also be prescribed to relieve pain and reduce inflammation.
  • If conservative measures fail to provide relief, surgery may be considered. Surgery typically involves removing the smaller bone fragment and smoothing the joint surface to reduce friction and alleviate pain.
  • In rare cases, surgery may involve fusing the two patellar fragments together to create a single patella.
  • With appropriate treatment, most people can return to their normal activities without significant limitations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Avulsion fracture; cylindrical cast. In avulsion fracture of PCL alone, the non-operative treatment relies on restoration of tibiofemoral relationship with immobilization, followed by physiotherapy. In the first 6 weeks, immobilization and limited weight bearing is achieved using a cylindrical cast in 15° flexion or with posterior support in the form of extension or dynamic anterior drawer brace to prevent subluxation of tibia.

 

 

Option C. Avulsion fracture; wire fixation. K-wire fixation is done for distal phalanx base avulsion fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image in the question shows bipartite patella which is a congenital fragmentation of patella i.e., the patella is made of two separate bones instead of one.
  • In this condition, it is always recommended to get an x-ray of the other knee also as this condition is bilateral in most cases.
  • It is treated by surgical removal of the smaller bone fragment when the conservative methods fail to provide relief.

questions.text: The most common ocular manifestation of COVID-19 is: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Follicular conjunctivitis

 

  • COVID-19 can cause ocular manifestations due to the presence of ACE-2 receptors on the cornea and conjunctiva, which are potential target tissues for SARS-CoV-2.

 

COVID-19:

 

  • Most common ocular symptoms: Dry eye or foreign body sensation, redness, tearing, itching, eye pain, and discharge.
  • Most common ocular manifestation: Mild follicular conjunctivitis, which can appear as the only sign and symptom of COVID-19.
  • Other less frequent ocular complications: Hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, dry eye disease, episcleritis, chemosis, and photophobia.
  • Intraocular complications that may occur: Retinal artery occlusions, hemorrhages, and cotton wool spots caused by complement-mediated thrombotic angiopathy.
  • Patients with conjunctivitis should undergo a nasopharyngeal RT-PCR test for COVID-19 to rule out systemic infection.
  • Physicians and ophthalmologists should exercise caution when examining patients with conjunctivitis and wear eye-protective gear in addition to face masks and other protective devices.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retinal vein thrombosis: While COVID-19 can cause thrombotic complications, retinal vein thrombosis is not commonly reported as a primary ocular manifestation of COVID-19.

 

Option B. Viral keratouveitis: There is limited evidence to suggest that COVID-19 directly causes viral keratouveitis. This condition involves inflammation of the cornea and uvea and is more commonly associated with other viruses.

 

Option D. Pseudomembranous conjunctivitis: Pseudomembranes in the context of conjunctivitis are not true membranes but rather a buildup of fibrin, inflammatory cells, and mucus. They can adhere to the conjunctival tissue and may cause a gritty or painful sensation in the eye. Some common causes of pseudomembranous conjunctivitis include:
 

  1. Bacterial Infections: Bacterial conjunctivitis, particularly caused by certain strains of bacteria like Corynebacterium diphtheriae or Streptococcus pneumoniae, can lead to the formation of pseudomembranes.
  2. Viral Infections: In rare cases, certain viruses, such as adenoviruses, can cause pseudomembranous conjunctivitis.
  3. Allergic Reactions: Severe allergic conjunctivitis can lead to the development of pseudomembranes, although this is less common.

 

Treatment for pseudomembranous conjunctivitis typically involves addressing the underlying cause, which may include antibiotics for bacterial infections or antiviral medications for viral infections. In some cases, topical steroids may be prescribed to reduce inflammation and relieve symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Follicular conjunctivitis is the most common ocular manifestation seen in patients with COVID-19, highlighting the virus's ability to affect multiple body systems including the eyes. This underscores the importance of protective measures for healthcare providers, such as wearing masks and eye protection when examining patients suspected of having COVID-19.

questions.text: Most radio-resistant phase of cell cycle? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) S

 

This is the synthesis phase, where DNA replication occurs. Cells in S phase are considered the most radio-resistant because they have already duplicated their genetic material, making them less susceptible to radiation-induced damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. G1 (Gap 1) Phase: Cells in the G1 phase are generally sensitive to radiation because they are actively engaged in normal metabolic activities and are preparing for DNA synthesis in the subsequent S phase.

 

Option C. G2 (Gap 2) Phase: The G2 phase is a period of further preparation for cell division (mitosis). Quite radiosensitive, due to checkpoint activation.

 

Option D. M Phase (Mitosis): This is the phase where cell division occurs, and the cell divides into two daughter cells. Cells in M phase are most sensitive to radiation.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child came with a lesion in the right eye and the histopathological image showed Flexner Wintersteiner rosettes. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retinoblastoma

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation of a lesion in the eye of a young child, along with the histopathological finding of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (small round blue tumor cells), strongly suggests the diagnosis of retinoblastoma.

 

Retinoblastoma is a malignant tumor of the retina that primarily affects young children. It arises from immature retinal cells called retinoblasts. The presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes is a characteristic histopathological feature of retinoblastoma. These rosettes are true rosettes, consisting of a ring of tumor cells surrounding a central lumen, resembling the primitive neuroepithelium.

 

It is important to distinguish Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes from Homer Wright rosettes, which are pseudo-rosettes. Homer Wright rosettes are characterized by tumor cells arranged around a central neuropil (tangled cell processes) and are seen in various tumors of neuroectodermal origin, such as neuroblastoma and medulloblastoma.

 

 

While retinoblastoma can show both true rosettes (Flexner-Wintersteiner) and pseudo-rosettes (Homer Wright), the presence of true rosettes is more specific for retinoblastoma in the context of an ocular tumor in a young child.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ocular melanoma: Ocular melanoma is a malignant tumor arising from melanocytes in the eye. It is more common in adults and does not typically show Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes on histopathology.

 

Option C. Rhabdomyosarcoma: Rhabdomyosarcoma is a malignant tumor of skeletal muscle origin. While it can occur in the orbit, it does not show Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes on histopathology.

 

Option D. Optic nerve glioma: Optic nerve glioma is a benign tumor arising from glial cells of the optic nerve. It is more common in children with neurofibromatosis type 1 but does not typically show Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes on histopathology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (true rosettes) on histopathology of an ocular lesion in a young child is highly suggestive of retinoblastoma. It is important to distinguish these true rosettes from Homer Wright pseudo-rosettes, which can be seen in various other neuroectodermal tumors.

questions.text: A patient presents with a combination of Casal's necklace, cheilosis, and stomatitis. Upon further examination, it is discovered that the individual has a diet deficient in a specific nutrient. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Niacin deficiency

 

Explanation:

 

The patient's symptoms—Casal's necklace, cheilosis, and stomatitis—are characteristic of niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency. Niacin deficiency leads to a condition known as pellagra, which is classically described by the "three Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. Casal's necklace, a photosensitive dermatitis appearing as a necklace-like distribution around the neck, is a hallmark of pellagra.

 

  • Casal's Necklace: A distinctive hyperpigmented rash in a necklace-like distribution due to sun exposure.

 

 

  • Cheilosis: Cracking and inflammation at the corners of the mouth, common in various B vitamin deficiencies.

 

 

  • Stomatitis: Inflammation of the mucous membrane of the mouth, also associated with B vitamin deficiencies.

 

Niacin can be synthesized from the amino acid tryptophan, making it an atypical vitamin. A deficiency in dietary tryptophan can also lead to niacin deficiency.

 

  

           Images  - photosensitive dermatitis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B12 deficiency: Typically presents with megaloblastic anemia and neurological symptoms, not the specific skin findings described here.

 

Option B. Riboflavin deficiency: Can cause cheilosis and stomatitis, but not Casal's necklace.

 

Option D. Vitamin C deficiency: Presents with symptoms of scurvy, such as bleeding gums and perifollicular hemorrhages, not the symptoms described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Niacin deficiency (pellagra) presents with characteristic symptoms including Casal's necklace, cheilosis, and stomatitis. Treatment involves supplementation with niacin (vitamin B3).

 

Note – Glossitis and cheilosis – occurs in B2, B3 and B6 deficiencies 60 mg of Tryptophan is used to synthesize 1 mg of Niacin

questions.text: Most common cause of blindness in children is:(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin A deficiency

 

The correct answer is Vitamin A Deficiency. It remains the leading cause of preventable blindness in children due to its severe impact on the cornea and overall eye health when left untreated.

 

Vitamin A deficiency is a major cause of preventable blindness in children, particularly in developing countries. It can lead to xerophthalmia, a condition that can progress to night blindness and more severe damage to the cornea, potentially resulting in complete blindness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glaucoma: Childhood glaucoma is rare compared to other causes of visual impairment in children. When it does occur, it can lead to blindness if not treated. However, it is not the most common cause of blindness in children globally.

 

Option C. Cataract: Cataracts in children can be congenital or develop in childhood, leading to blindness if not treated. Pediatric cataract is a significant cause of visual impairment in children, but it is not as common as vitamin A deficiency in causing blindness.

 

Option D. Refractive Error: Refractive errors, such as myopia (nearsightedness), hyperopia (farsightedness), and astigmatism, are common in children. If left uncorrected, they can significantly impair vision but are not typically considered a direct cause of blindness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin A deficiency is the most common cause of preventable blindness in children in developing countries.
